title-group.article-title: Re: A. Sierakowski and D. Elliot. Amputation for pain in a thumb – not an advisable treatment. J Hand Surg Eur. 2013, 38: 331–3

contrib-group.aff: Consultant Plastic, Reconstructive and Hand Surgeon, Bedford Hospital, Bedford, UK. Email: pjm418@btinternet.com

permissions.copyright-holder: The British Society for Surgery of the Hand

body.p: This timely article reinforces the old teaching that ‘you cannot amputate pain’. The authors also quite properly emphasise the importance of focal local anaesthetic blocks in analysing the source of the symptoms. This is a much underused technique of inestimable value in such difficult situations.

However, in the cases used to illustrate the authors’ message, there is one piece of vital information that they have not given us: Was there any ongoing litigation or compensation issue? Such is the enormous pressure from the contemporary medico-legal process on patients to demonstrate symptoms that it is vital for the clinician to both ask and record the patient’s status in this respect. Doubtless Sierowski and Elliot did enquire, but for those clinicians who do not there are major risks of inappropriate surgery for both patient and doctor.

p.bold: Re: A. Sierakowski and D. Elliot. Amputation for pain in a thumb – not an advisable treatment. J Hand Surg Eur. 2013, 38: 331–3

body.p:
Thank you for this comment. While it makes a good point, there were no medico-legal/compensation issues in these three cases. The only pressure on the clinicians was from the patients to provide relief of the overwhelming neurogenic pain. Any reader who has had toothache, or has read Robert Burns’ poem ‘Address to the Tooth-Ache’
My curse upon thy venom’d stang,That shoots my tortur’d gums alang;And thro’ my lugs gies mony a twang,Wi’ gnawing vengeance;Tearing my nerves wi’ bitter pang,Like racking engines!
------
But thee -- thou hell o’ a’ diseases,Aye mocks our groan!
will appreciate the magnitude of this pressure from the patient to ‘do something’.
